awd_titl_txt: DMREF - Material Intelligence for Accelerated Design of Biologically-Interfaced Single-Layered Devices
awd_abstract_narration:
Rapidly expanding machine learning (ML) and artificial intelligence (AI) algorithms offer tools for Materials Science and Engineering (MSE), unprecedented just a few of years ago. Even the most advanced traditional tools today (microfluidics, advanced modeling, and supercomputers) cannot keep up with the opportunities offered by data intensive ML/AI tools. The main barrier to achieve the goals laid out in the Materials Genome Initiative (MGI) strategic plan is the difficulty to access clean, curated, comprehensive, meaningful, and most of all, standardized data that can be used in predictive design and modeling of engineered systems, especially true in highly complex and dynamic interfaces between biology and materials science. The ability to deploy these powerful algorithms in domain sciences has remained limited due to the sheer number of dimensions of the parameter space and enormous variability in the data. With the goal of overcoming the current barriers, this project aims to develop a modular software framework, dubbed Materials Intelligence (Mat-I) towards accelerating discovery and innovation in MSE. By exploiting Mat-I technology, the scientific community has the high likelihood of accelerating research, and the collaborating industry (Microsoft, Amazon, Google, NVIDIA, Real Networks, Proctor and Gamble, Allen Institute for Artificial Intelligence, and Intel) will have the crucial tools to develop materials and methods with tailored bio-nano interfaces at the critical intersection of biology, solid-state systems, and informatics in designing devices such as bionanosensors for cancer diagnostics, biomolecular fuel cells for energy harvesting, and neuromorphic networks towards brain-like computers. The project will educate the next generation of innovative scientists, undergraduates, PhDs, and post-doctoral researchers, bolstering the traditional competitive edge of the US at the world stage.

The technical aim of the convergence science team, with expertise in genomics, computer science, physics, and materials science and engineering, is to construct a modular Mat-I software framework towards accelerating discovery and innovation. The research will generate and make accessible comprehensive maps among the input space of structures (peptides and single atomic layer solids, the smallest viable entities in biology and physical sciences, respectively) to the output target space of physical properties under a wide range of experimental conditions. The goal is to learn correlations among the three parameters such that, given the sequence/structure representations and experimental conditions, one can then predict the output physical properties, which may be adapted to complex engineered solutions. The proposed approach will employ, enhance, and develop specific mathematical, statistical, and information approaches for discovery in materials engineering that will combine physical, information, and biosciences. Given a set of measurements, the team will apply ML/AI to make inferences and learn a model of the true underlying process and, using these inferences and quantifications of uncertainty, the team will devise test-beds to maximize the information gained with respect to the model. By collecting data and making correlations in an iterative loop, the pace of discovery will be accelerated in closing the knowledge gaps faster than standard methods. The research will use model selection, robust statistics, and adaptive learning, and prototype validation in both static and dynamic representations of bio-nano interfaces. The project will establish foundational rules of a wide range of key wetware devices for technology and medicine through neural network formation by incorporating biology with solid-state devices of the future, the ultimate goal of the project.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

perf_inst.perf_str_addr: Mater Sci and Eng., Roberts Hall

por.por_cntn:
The budget of this project has not been available since January 2020. Therefore, nothing to report.

 

Here the abstract of this project:

Overview: Rapidly expanding machine learning and artificial intelligence algorithms offer tools for MaterialsScience and Engineering that was unprecedented just a few of years ago. The main barrier to achieve thegoals laid out in the MGI strategic plan, in general, is the difficulty to access clean, curated,comprehensive, meaningful, and standardized data that can be used in predictive design and modeling.Ability to deploy these powerful algorithms in the domain sciences has been limited, owing to the sheernumber of dimensions of the parameter space and heterogeneity in the data. In the first phase of MGI, wehave implemented high throughput selection of solid-binding peptides, developed protocols to encodemolecular components mathematically with promising predictive power, and undertaken efforts toobserve self-assembly and signal transduction in simple devices. In DMREF Phase-2 research, we planfor high throughput functional peptides selection, develop experiments to characterize large datasets, andquantify signal transduction through local and low-temperature techniques, towards implementing a large,relational database with closed-loop data-architecture integrated with powerful Artificial Intelligencemodels for predictive design of hybrid test-bed devices.

Key Words: AI, Molecular biomimetics, molecular-recognition, peptides, 2D-Solids.

Intellectual Merit:The proposed convergent science-based MAT-I platform will employ specific mathematical, statistical,and theoretical approaches in AI for accelerated discovery in materials science and engineering,combining physical-, bio- and information-sciences. The physical entities will be encoded mathematicallyin terms of their smaller molecular components. Using fingerprints and data-fusion techniques, we willconvert all processing-conditions, targeted properties and structural components into a homogeneousencoding to train the neural networks with otherwise heterogeneous data. The project will address, inTask-1, structural features constructed by integrating the carefully designed experiments with hierarchicalcomputational modeling and predictive design; in Task-2, predict the best outcome under differentprocessing conditions, carried out by iterative high throughput experimentation and closed-loop dataarchitecture; and in Task-3, implement iterative test-bed measurements of target properties based on solidstate physics to predictively design new device functions. Iterative closed-loop data-pipelines will beestablished for automatic curation, collection, standardization, storage, caching, analysis, visualizationand dissemination of data at the bio/nano interface. By more detailed understanding of the intricacies ofthe peptide/2D solid interfaces, e.g., electrochemical conditions, molecular recognition characteristics ofdifferent and mutant peptides sequences and the physical changes, e.g., electronic density of states, in the2D solid will be established. The ultimate goal of the project is to make accelerated strides in innovationfor seamlessly bridging biology and solid-state nanodevices of the future.

Broader Impacts:Applying Mat-I platform technology by the scientific community has a very high likelihood ofaccelerating research and designing materials and devices with tailored bio/nano interfaces at the criticalintersection of biology, solid-state materials, and informatics, such as bionanosensors for cancerdiagnostics, biomolecular fuel cells, and neuromorphic interfaces. The project will educate the nextgeneration of innovative scientists at the Undergraduate, Graduate and Post-Graduate levels to maintainthe competitive edge of the USA on the world stage. To bridge the gap between academia/industry andgeneral public, we will establish Science Tuesdays (Science Cafe) at Bulldog News in collaboration withThe New York Times; Summer Mat-I Abalone Camp for High School Students/Teachers (GEMSECeScienceInstitute partnership); New UG and Grad classes to push data science, biology and informaticsinto materials research (with eScience, Neuroscience and MolES Institutes); Web-based materials designstudio;Freshman Interest Group (with classes in molecular biology, data acquisition/analytics, and deeplearning); innovation platforms through Materials Hackathons and VR game design; Outreach viaFacebook, Twitter and Instagram; and engage in events local- and statewide in partnership withMicrosoft, Amazon, Google, Allen Institute for AI, Allen Institute for Brain Science, Institute for SystemsBiology, and Pacific Science Center.


Last Modified: 12/22/2022
Modified by: Mehmet Sarikaya
por.por_txt_cntn:
The budget of this project has not been available since January 2020. Therefore, nothing to report.
